issue_comments.body:
On Saturday, April 11, 2015, Kanstantsin Shautsou notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @ndeloof https://github.com/ndeloof should we call @stephenc
> https://github.com/stephenc for help? Credentials code looks complex
> and as i see almost all plugins not implementing credentials because.
> Is there some design description of this credentials plugin? I don't
> understand why every plugin should implement so basic Credential types.

My rule of thumb. If the backing credential information could conceivably
be synced with another consumer of credentials, then use a common type.

The first test case is username/password. People like ldap backed sso. So
do not create a credential type to hold username&password because that
causes at best interface envy and at worst class envy. There is converter
support to help roll back if you shipped such a mistake

The second case is ssh key because you likely will use the same key against
multiple services.

I'm on my phone so cannot see what is going on here but I am strongly
against every plugin and their mother implementing credential types:
- confuses users as to which type they need to create
- creates type envy causing inter-locking plugin dependencies
- really just a hack around using domain specs/reqs

—

> https://github.com/jenkinsci/github-plugin/pull/45#issuecomment-91880053
> .

J

On Saturday, April 11, 2015, Kanstantsin Shautsou notifications@github.com
wrote:

> have wanted to. Most of this I have covered with some people implementing

I think I need to document it out as a number of people are getting
confused all at the same time.

> 1) In case of github plugin credentials: a) username+password,
> 
> This should be a standard user-pass. No special type. If somebody has
> github enterprise their username/password might be synced to corp ldap, so
> we want them to only have one credential to update every 90 days, not send
> them running to update 50 different credentials before jenkins pushes three
> failed logins and locks their account out
> 
>  b) token,
> 
> So here the case is how is the token generated. This is presumably
> generated by github or github enterprise. It would this make sense to store
> the "issuer" as a field and provide a button that initiates a web-flow
> against the issuer to generate the token. In that case "issuer" would need
> to be a global config so we can give the user a drop down if issuers to
> trigger the web flow against.

This token might well implement some other interfaces or you may use the
auth-tokens-api to convert it for use.

The point is that the web flow needs are specific to the class of issuer,
so you would have a gh/GHE specific credential type for this

>  c) (probably) token + secure field(used for decrypting incoming hooks
> data) - can be reused by other GH plugins (for example i created new
> github-pullrequest-plugin and will be glad to fix/implement in right place
> credentials).
> 
> A similar analysis would apply here.
> 
> 2) Also i not really understand how URL should be matched/related/bundled
> in credentials. From one side GitHub related passwords are just GH related,
> but on other hand they can used for git https checkout communication.
> 
> When you are asking the user to select credentials you have a target that
> the credentials are for, you use that to generate the domain requirements.
> Typically you would use the git url, but you can add additional
> requirements (of custom types) as you see fit.

The user creates a credential domain and attached domain specifications to
that domain. They then put the credentials for that domain into the domain
and presto those credentials show up.

Example:

Create a domain with the spec: *.acme.com
Put user/pass from ldap.acme.com into domain.
When asking for credentials to check out from git.acme.com that user pass
will be available.

Hopefully this helps thinking around this pull request

review_comments.body:
@ndeloof the token is really a password with restricted permissions. The user gets to select how much permissions to give the token. To my way of thinking a better way would be to have domain specifications and domain requirements that match the permissions that can be granted to a github token. That way users can put the tokens into the domains that match the permissions they granted.

A username/password would have full permissions, while a username/token would be in a different domain. As such I am unclear that the token needs to be a separate type from the username/password. Things that would argue for a separate type:
- The auth with a token being different than the auth with a password, e.g. when using a password you have to pass `Authenication: Basic ...` but with a token you have to pass `Authentication: Token ...`
- You are providing a special API to generate the token (e.g. via a web flow)... if the resulting token behaves just like a password in terms of authentication then you would implement the `StandardUsernamePasswordsCredentials` interface but use a button or such to control generating/validation/updating the token and you would not display a "password" field.
- Perhaps some other exotic use case I cannot think of right now.

Absence the above, I would favour not creating a special type for this.

In any case I think you need to look at creating some `GitHubPermissionDomainRequirement` and `GitHubPermissionDomainSpecification` style class(es) so that users can put tokens into domains that match what the tokens are good for.

If you are providing a specialized UI to provide for generating/revalidating/regenerating the token, then yes the server that you operate against (i.e. "the origin of authentication truth") is part of the credential. This does not mean that the credential cannot be used against other services, e.g. they may be pass-through services or they may be services that delegate auth to a github enterprise instance.

So you want to provide a different UI flow, but my understanding is that the resulting token is used just like a password. So you probably want to implement `StandardUsernamePasswordCredentials` _because_ the token is used to authenticate _as if it were a password_. Because you are providing an alternative UI flow it makes sense to be a separate credential type, but the actual stored credentials (to my understanding, correct me if I am wrong) is a username and a _"password"_ (much like the app specific passwords that GMail lets you generate with 2FA enabled... The app you give that "password" to does not know it is a token and not your actual password) On Sunday, April 12, 2015, Nicolas De loof notifications@github.com wrote: > In src/main/java/com/cloudbees/jenkins/github/AccessTokenCredential.java > https://github.com/jenkinsci/github-plugin/pull/45#discussion_r28201391: > > > +import org.kohsuke.stapler.QueryParameter; > > + > > +import java.io.IOException; > > +import java.util.Arrays; > > +import java.util.List; > > + > > +/** > > - \* @author Nicolas De Loof > > - */ > > +public class AccessTokenCredential extends BaseStandardCredentials implements StandardUsernameCredentials { > > + > > - private final String githubServer; > > + > > - private final String username; > > + > > - private final Secret token; > > @stphenc my intent here was to offer option to create a token from jenkins > UI, using a classic username/password authentication to github token > generation API. The token then for sure can be considered being some > username/password item, but the related UI is a distinct one. > > — > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub > https://github.com/jenkinsci/github-plugin/pull/45/files#r28201391. ## Sent from my phone

[JENKINS-36445] Show first 7 characters of SHA1 in change log hyperlink (#128)

Most git repository browsing systems (bitbucket, cgit, github, gitweb)
display a short form of the SHA1 (commonly the first 7 characters) with
a clickable hyperlink that will take them to a page that includes the
full SHA1.

This change reduces the visible SHA1 text in the list of changes to the
first 7 characters of the SHA1, consistent with those other repository
browsers. It also adds assertions that the expected format is used and
simplifies the existing annotator tests.

If any additional formatting changes are needed (not that I'm saying they are needed), it can be made after the merge.
Merged #24, so I'm closing this.

I find it confusing that `GitHubSCM` doesn't extend from `SCM`, and in looking at the code, I think existing `GitHubRepositoryName` serves this purpose pretty well.

This also creates code duplication between `GitHubPushTrigger` and `GitHubCommitNotifier`. I think the right thing to do is to move the code that computes associated `GitHubRepositoryName`s from `GitHubTrigger` to some independent location.

Accordingly, I've fixed this in a bit different as a part of JENKINS-18165 fix in a1f53cdb15bcddc0e719ec6eacf03d3fe6ea5e07. I believe it addresses your use case.

As @jrtc27 noted, this commit has whitespace only changes that hides the actual change. As an etiquette, one doesn't submit a pull request that does that.

Furthermore, I think what you want to do in your case is to use Git plugin's exclude committers functionality to exclude commits made by Jenkins, not push by Jenkins.
As requested in PR #31, closing this.
... as a duplicate.

On the point [oleg noted](https://github.com/jenkinsci/github-plugin/pull/37#issuecomment-32063276) about the security issue of revealing the credential to a user-specified server, I don't think it happens.

Each credential comes with its own API endpoint specification, and this is the only URL against which the operation happens.

So I think this change is safe.
Closed #37. I investigated the security concern from @oleg-nenashev in that PR, and I think it is safe.
This is an invalid change.

It's quite possible that I'm not understanding this, but if you are interested in scheduling builds only for specific branches, the right thing to do is to set the branch spec in the Git SCM configuration.

All this plugin is doing is to schedule a polling, and it's up to the Git plugin to determine if the change pushed is worth the build.

There are lots of criteria when it comes to what is considered an interesting change and what is not. We can't add every one of them in this plugin. We've learned that lesson in the Subversion plugin and the Git v1 plugin.

commits.message: GitHubRepositoryNameTest: add ssh:// URL schema tests

Handle ssh:// URLs that doesn't contain git@

It is possible to specify and use github.com URLs as
ssh://github.com/username/repo, as credentials used
for SCM configuration usually include username.
This change would allow to properly parse such URLs.
Fixed incorrect proxy configuration of GitHubLoginFunction

Use `TransientActionFactory` instead of `GithubProjectProperty.getJobActions`.

This makes the "GitHub" link also show up for Workflow projects.
Allow Commit Notifications to be used as Workflow Build Steps.

don't be platform specific in checkstyle.

While notable the existing checkstyle means the build is DOA on windows
that uses CRLF as a system linefeed.

Whilst this change enforces unix termination, it will break windows
clients configured with `core.autocrlf=true" but changing files can lead
to platform specific test failures (especially with resource files under
test) so EOL conversion is in this persons eyes evil and to be avoided at
all costs.

It would probably be worthwile to setup .gitattributes in the root of the
repository to stop any eol conversion - but I shall leave that up to the
owners for an excersize at their leisure.

pull_requests.body: This change adds the git reference and head commit as arguments to triggered jobs. This allows Jenkins jobs to implement specialized logic. pull_requests.title: Support aborted build status reporting
pull_requests.body: This pull request supports reporting aborted builds to Github as errors. Currently, aborted builds use the default status which is pending. This can be confusing for automated tools. This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/133)

Content-type is called 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' in the github UI

be careful, the event header might have a value like "push" or "pull", but the content-type is responsible to whether the content my be encoded or not. In the case of the service hook, the user has no chance to change the content-type so, it will be `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`. But in the case of a WebHook, the default value is  `application/json`.
The best in this situation would probably be to implement this the same way as in the Bitbucket Plugin: https://github.com/jenkinsci/bitbucket-plugin/blob/master/src/main/java/com/cloudbees/jenkins/plugins/BitbucketHookReceiver.java#L53-L56
...but `application/vnd.github+form`is just wrong.

In terms of the `X-Github-Event`: I have talked to the GitHub Support and after the confusion with this fix - they might not include the header into the enterprise version.

I think this commit is incomplete; using the commit status API requires authentication to GitHub, which requires credentials. However, credentials can only be configured in the global config page if the user is allowing the GitHub plugin to automatically manage service hooks; if manual service hook management is enabled, there is no place to configure credentials (in other words, the same credentials are now serving another purpose).

I believe this can be fixed by moving the 'GitHub Credential' section of GitHubPushTrigger/global.jelly outside the radioblock section, but it might be even better to create a separate global config area for the credentials, since using them _only_ for the commit status updates is unrelated to push triggering.
Yeah, I was thinking about that this morning. That would help in another way: instead of the commit status update 'guessing' which credentials to use, the proper one could be explicitly selected.

Ok, so I've got this working now:
- I updated to the released version of 1.6.
- I finally got the port forwarding setup so that I could use push-based build triggering rather than polling

I strongly suspect that having the latter setup correctly caused the commit status API to start working correctly. Other than the port forwarding / firewalling setup (Github IPs here: https://help.github.com/articles/what-ip-addresses-does-github-use-that-i-should-whitelist) there are no major downsides to moving to push-based.

@ludofleury yes, it now works fine for me in version 1.6.
Previously I was using polling rather than using the Github hook to trigger builds.

Setup Steps:
- Install plugin
- In "Configure System", make sure that "Let Jenkins auto-manage hook URLs" is selected.
- Enter a github username & password. Test credentials.
  For each job that you want the build status applied to:
- Set the correct Github Project
- Check "Build when a change is pushed to GitHub" under build triggers
- Add a post-build action "Set build status on Github commit"

In your github account, setup the Jenkins hook.

With this set up, builds are now triggered by pushed to github, commit SHAs are linked to github and the status of each commit is written to github.

commit_comments.body: Yep. The API token was a relic from API v1 and v2. It was completely deprecated back in March of 2012. This change updates the plugin to be compatible with API v3 using OAuth tokens.

Based on my understanding the old API tokens only worked with APIv2, which was officially shutdown over a year ago. There's no way to get an API token like that any longer. To get an equivalent OAuth token, a user just has to go to https://github.com/settings/applications and create a Personal Access Token (or generate a more narrowly scoped token via the Authorizations API (http://developer.github.com/v3/oauth/#oauth-authorizations-api).

+1 on this pull request. The GitHub hook message handling was failing silently for me with the current release of the plugin, and this patch provides the solution. I'm sure this is confusing some other users out there.

In master, GitHubWebHook now gets around the matchers in GitHubRepositoryName (which require .git suffixes) by using its own matcher and a multi-arg constructor to GitHubRepositoryName. 

However, the GithubWebHook action checks against each job configured on the Jenkins server with GitHubPushTrigger. The GitHubRepositoryName object properly constructed from the GitHub hook message by GitHubWebHook is being compared against those in a set created by GitHubPushTrigger.getGitHubRepositories() via GitHubRepositoryName.create(), which still uses the old single-string constructor and therefore the restrictive matchers. That constructor returns nulls and GitHubPushTrigger.getGitHubRepositories() therefore returns an empty set, which of course does not contain an object equal to the GitHubRepositoryName object extracted from the Github hook message.

This pull request neatly solves the problem by moving the matching logic back into the single-arg constructor.

Before changes:

```
May 15, 2013 6:00:11 PM com.cloudbees.jenkins.GitHubWebHook processGitHubPayload
INFO: Received POST for https://github.com/openplans/OpenTripPlanner
May 15, 2013 6:00:11 PM com.cloudbees.jenkins.GitHubRepositoryName create
INFO: Constructing from URL https://github.com/openplans/OpenTripPlanner
May 15, 2013 6:00:11 PM com.cloudbees.jenkins.GitHubRepositoryName create
INFO: URL matches java.util.regex.Matcher[pattern=https?://([^/]+)/([^/]+)/([^/]+) region=0,44 lastmatch=https://github.com/openplans/OpenTripPlanner]
May 15, 2013 6:00:11 PM com.cloudbees.jenkins.GitHubRepositoryName create
INFO: Object is GitHubRepository[host=github.com,username=openplans,repository=OpenTripPlanner]
May 15, 2013 6:00:11 PM com.cloudbees.jenkins.GitHubRepositoryName create
INFO: Constructing from URL http://github.com/openplans/OpenTripPlanner/
May 15, 2013 6:00:11 PM com.cloudbees.jenkins.GitHubRepositoryName create
WARNING: Could not match URL http://github.com/openplans/OpenTripPlanner/
```

The incoming URL from the GitHub hook message is matched, but the repository name from the Jenkins job is not.

With changes to the regular expressions used for URL matching:

The event header value can be "push", "pull_request" and many others. Most of these events below generated their "X-Github-Event" type. This plugin only supports the payload for "push", so if you pass the payload for "pull_request" into processGithubPayload, it will throw exceptions and its not clear why it breaks. That was whole point of adding this change.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/701733/3656576/0262d898-1188-11e4-94e2-3d49a369d997.png)

The json structure for the payload is different for each of eventTypes. As far as content-type is concerned. The webhook UI from github actually allows you to choose it

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/701733/3656658/06339de4-1189-11e4-98c9-744c74322118.png)

For the actual language of the error message, this commit doesn't actually change the error message when no payload is specified.

```
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Not intended to be browsed interactively (must specify payload parameter). " Make sure payload version is 'application/vnd.github+form'.");
```

We should definitely fix the above error message as well as its obviously just wrong.

The only thing this commit adds is if the event is not of "push" type it won't call processGithubPayload and instead it throws an exception, which is lot better than calling the method and having that throw exceptions that are hard to read.
`application/x-www-form-urlencoded` is what github sends, making this a very misleading error message.

This is not correct.  There is a distinct difference between `git@github.com:jenkinsci/jenkins.git` and `ssh://git@github.com/jenkinsci/jenkins.git`.  It might look like they are interchangeable to you, but that is incorrect.  In fact, by default, the second one would be identical to: `ssh://git@github.com:22/jenkinsci/jenkins.git`.  Note that the SSH port number must be specified via a colon.  With your change, you are now assuming that the path to the git repository is "22/jenkinsci/jenkins.git", and that is wrong.

Take Gerrit code review, as an example:  `ssh://jenkins@gerrit.company.com:29418/jenkinsci/jenkins.git`.  This is the proper format of an `ssh://` URL.  Your change makes that incompatible.

Having a look at this PR to see if it could help with a problem we're having.

Are you sure that `ref` always points to `ref/heads/`? AFAIK if you push tags to GitHub then `ref` could refer to `refs/tags/`. An actual event we see can look like:

``` json
{
  "ref": "refs/tags/[TAG]",
  "after": "[SAH1]",
  "before": "0000000000000000000000000000000000000000",
  "created": true,
  "deleted": false,
  "forced": true,
  "compare": "https://github.com/[ORG]/[REPO]/compare/[TAG]",
  "commits": [],
 ...
```

Or am I misunderstanding where `ref` comes from?

I think we do want tags - I can see cases were it is useful anyway.

I'm making the required change now.

Looking at this further, it looks like we don't need to deal with tags specifically, because the sha1 matches the tag. Instead we should restrict the branches to ref/heads. This PR looks like it would do bad things with anything that didnt match ref/heads.
